content.raw:
Maybe something like `is_end_effector` would be a more appropriate term?

Could you go into a bit more detail on how you plan on using this and why it needs to be part of the SDF spec?

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
I am implementing jog function of a robot manipulator. When any of the link is clicked, I need to attach a visual handle to the end link \(or end effector if there is one\). So when the model is read in, I need to know which link is the end link.

is\_end\_effector is also a feasible name for this purpose.
content.html:
I am implementing jog function of a robot manipulator. When any of the link is clicked, I need to attach a visual handle to the end link (or end effector if there is one). So when the model is read in, I need to know which link is the end link.

is_end_effector is also a feasible name for this purpose.

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw: Ok, I understood your use case. But couldn't you get this information from somewhere other than the `<link>` element? If you're using Gazebo, you could specify the link's name within a `<plugin>` tag, for example. The reason I'm asking is that we should be careful not to make the SDF spec larger than it needs to be.
content.html: Ok, I understood your use case. But couldn't you get this information from somewhere other than the <link> element? If you're using Gazebo, you could specify the link's name within a <plugin> tag, for example. The reason I'm asking is that we should be careful not to make the SDF spec larger than it needs to be.

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
<plugin> is .so file for a <model>. Theoretically I could do the following in a plugin:

```
for all links
    if link name is "link_6"
        set the link's is_end to true
```

But this does not feel right. I have to hard code the link’s name to know if the link is an end link. Anytime I modified the link name in SDF file, I have to change C\+\+ code as well.

“is\_end” is local information for a link. If it is not attached to a link directly, it is hard to recover it from elsewhere.

Is there a better way to do this?
content.html:
<plugin> is .so file for a <model>. Theoretically I could do the following in a plugin:

for all links
    if link name is "link_6"
        set the link's is_end to true

But this does not feel right. I have to hard code the link’s name to know if the link is an end link. Anytime I modified the link name in SDF file, I have to change C++ code as well.

“is_end” is local information for a link. If it is not attached to a link directly, it is hard to recover it from elsewhere.

Is there a better way to do this?

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
> Is there a better way to do this?

Yup, you can add any arbitrary parameters inside the `<plugin>` tag for example:

```
<model ...
  <plugin ...
    <end_effector>link_6</end_effector>
  </plugin>
</model>
```

Then inside your plugin's `Load` function, you do

```
void Load(physics::ModelPtr _model, sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
{
  auto linkName = _sdf->Get<std::string>("end_effector");
  auto link = _model->GetLink(linkName);
}
```
content.html:
Is there a better way to do this?

Yup, you can add any arbitrary parameters inside the <plugin> tag for example:

<model ...
  <plugin ...
    <end_effector>link_6</end_effector>
  </plugin>
</model>

Then inside your plugin's Load function, you do

void Load(physics::ModelPtr _model, sdf::ElementPtr _sdf)
{
  auto linkName = _sdf->Get<std::string>("end_effector");
  auto link = _model->GetLink(linkName);
}

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
Thanks. I didn’t know there can be arbitrary parameters inside the <plugin> tag. Is this specified by

```
  <element copy_data="true" required="*">
    <description>This is a special element that should not be specified in an SDF file. It automatically copies child elements into the SDF element so that a plugin can access the data.</description>
  </element>
```
content.html:
Thanks. I didn’t know there can be arbitrary parameters inside the <plugin> tag. Is this specified by

  <element copy_data="true" required="*">
    <description>This is a special element that should not be specified in an SDF file. It automatically copies child elements into the SDF element so that a plugin can access the data.</description>
  </element>

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw: yes, that ensures that arbitrary child elements are passed on
content.html: yes, that ensures that arbitrary child elements are passed on

I am just providing some extra properties for the model.

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
Are you using SDFormat with Gazebo or with another simulator?

On Gazebo, the simulator is responsible for handling all elements present in the official SDF spec. If a downstream developer wants to implement a plugin that adds extra functionality to simulation, they can add parameters specific to the plugin within the `<plugin>` tag. That's why that tag supports any arbitrary argument.

I'm not seeing a pull request to [Gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/) adding code to parse the new element you're proposing, so I suspect you're either using it within a plugin or with a different simulator. If you're using it with a plugin, you should put the tag inside `<plugin>`. If you're using a different simulator, then we should talk a bit more about the specific use case.
content.html:
Are you using SDFormat with Gazebo or with another simulator?

On Gazebo, the simulator is responsible for handling all elements present in the official SDF spec. If a downstream developer wants to implement a plugin that adds extra functionality to simulation, they can add parameters specific to the plugin within the <plugin> tag. That's why that tag supports any arbitrary argument.

I'm not seeing a pull request to Gazebo adding code to parse the new element you're proposing, so I suspect you're either using it within a plugin or with a different simulator. If you're using it with a plugin, you should put the tag inside <plugin>. If you're using a different simulator, then we should talk a bit more about the specific use case.

pullrequest.title: Add must_be_end_link element to link sdf

content.raw:
I am developing a robot manipulator simulator \(not Gazebo, not Gazebo plugin\), and I am using SDF to describe the robot model.

I am implementing the jog function. In jogging mode, when any of the links is clicked, I need to find the end effector of the robot, and attach a handle to it to let the user jog the end effector manually. So I need to tell the program which link is the end link of the robot.
content.html:
I am developing a robot manipulator simulator (not Gazebo, not Gazebo plugin), and I am using SDF to describe the robot model.

I am implementing the jog function. In jogging mode, when any of the links is clicked, I need to find the end effector of the robot, and attach a handle to it to let the user jog the end effector manually. So I need to tell the program which link is the end link of the robot.
